bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Clarence Powell Thorne was born in 1874, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He was the son of Civil War veteran, J. Powell Rogers Thorne and Amy Theodosious Zeigenfuss. He was married to Elsa Quaker. He was a right-wing ideologue and died in New York City, in August 1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are the papers of an eccentric, independent crusader for "the American Purpose" as set forth in the Preamble to the Constitution. The papers consist of typescripts of books and articles, correspondence, and related printed matter. All of these are arranged in a single chronological sequence, with the exception of a (partial) bibliography placed at the beginning and a folder of undated materials at the end.
Thorne's typescripts, in all or nearly all cases, are either unpublished or were privately printed and circulated.

The correspondence includes letters from, and copies of letters to, presidents, congressmen, right-wing political organizations, and publishers and newspaper editors. Many of the letters to Thorne are short and formal acknowledgments, but there are a number of letters from Reps. Will Rogers of Oklahoma and Louis Thomas McFadden of Pennsylvania. Thorne also carried on a long correspondence with the Yale University Library. Most of the originals of these letters are now in the Librarian's Records, but xerox copies of some of the more substantive communications (covering the years 1936-1956) have been added to the papers.
The papers cover the period 1913-1957, and are arranged in four boxes.
